Author: phillip#4197
Content:
@MikeMK  I don't know if it's really correct to say tech is lucrative.  I do think though, with technology and software in particular (because it's basically free), the potential to bring huge value or  return on investment.  If I got paid based on how much money my customer made/saved I'd be retired by now.  But, if I can help make my customer rich/save money then they're happy to overlook any of my deficiencies.  For example, if can help deliver a product that will start saving a tour bus company $100,000/month in fuel costs, the customer will not care if I know the right CSS for something or other.   So, my point is software can have these huge variances between what it costs and what it pays back.  Of course, I've seen several projects with tons of funding turn into zero value--so there's that too (maybe that's why I don't charge based on customer profits).  

Anyway, from reading your comments my only "advice" (please only take it for what it's worth) is to maybe try a multifaceted approach to learning all this.  Personally, using the vocabulary in real live speech with others (or chat on computer) is huge for me.  Trying to teach others is great.  I wrote a few books and taught Flash back in the day, and most of the time I was needing to learn what I was going to teach only days before teaching.  But having a variety of ways to jump into this industry is a great approach in my opinion.

Author: phillip#4197
Content:
When you do "npm install something" it puts the files for "something" in the node_modules folder... but it doesn't modify the package.json file.  By addng "--save" or "--save-dev" it puts an entry as a dependency in the package.json file.  
When you want to share your project or open it elsewhere, you can send just that package.json file... do "npm install" from the same directory... and it goes and installs all the pieces you have specified in the package.json file. So, if it's all done correctly, the person trying to run your code won't have to know to do npm install react react-native  etc.

Author: phillip#4197
Content: The whole model of react is that, given a state (that is set of variables) the entire screen including child components can be drawn using the values of those variables.   If you want to make a change, consider the whole thing starts over... the new state is used to draw the screen appropriately.  This model is different than one where you start with the initial values and then make edits to the state and change the look of individual parts.  In theory either approach works, but redrawing everything from the top down (though react takes care to be efficient) is simpler in many ways.

Author: phillip#4197
Content: also, it's easier to test because you're never relying on two or three things happening first.

Content:
RE: final project, seems like those requirements are wide open.  I tend to add redux to everything I do--react or even vanilla javascript.  I gives you a nice standardized way to handle all "actions" so it's not like I'm architecting an event system every time.  Also, it helps avoid the desire to make deeply nested components "talk up" to their ancestors.  One idea to help think of a project is to find an API out there that you'd like to play with.

RE: redux resources, the docs are great https://redux.js.org/ and I just notice this very good video series is free: https://egghead.io/courses/getting-started-with-redux     If you go through one of those 4 minute videos and you're anything like me, it could take you an hour to feel like you have a clue what's going on. @Dillon You should introduce a delay between the user input and the search query.

If you have any advice or can point me to some materials let me know.

For eg, Jordan wrote this code
const results = await response.text()
,where response is the response after fetching a URL.
How would I know to await .text() function, when response has already been computed?

Author: saf#6475
Content:
Well, I am not quite sure what you mean, 
But generally if you are making a network request, you await the result, because what you get is a promise object,  now response too has a lot of things and inorder to fetch say, after getting the response, you do result.json()  to get the actual content, now .json()  too responds with a promise so you need  to await that.

If your response.text() returns a promise you need to await that too. Inorder to find out whether it is a promise or not just print it out and check its type.
